intro: Papaver radicatum var. pseudoradicatum, commonly known as the false poppy, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It features a basal rosette of broad, wavy-edged leaves that are typically gray-green in color. The plant produces striking, showy flowers with bright orange petals and a central greenish-yellow disk, which bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or open habitats. The species is notable for its medicinal properties, though it is not widely cultivated for commercial use.
